chunk_title: Objective and Justification – General Objective
chunk: 2.1 The objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to promote a better performance in the water and sanitation sector in Colombia, working at the utility level as well as at the public entities level.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Sector Progress and Institutional Strengthening
chunk: 2.2 During the last three decades, Colombia has considerably strengthened the water and sanitation (W&S) sector. The country set up a comprehensive legal and institutional framework to improve water and sanitation services. The IDB in Colombia has promoted best practices in the W&S sector in a consistent manner since 2016 to improve W&S service provision through technical cooperations such as “Comprehensive development of Urban Water and Sewerage Companies in Colombia (CO-T1457) - phase I” and “Pilot of Alternative Financing Mechanisms for the Drinking Water Sector in Colombia CO-T1556.”

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – VEI Partnership and Rural Utility Support
chunk: From 2019 through 2024, the IDB has worked in partnership with a non-for-profit consortium of public Dutch utilities (VEI) whose mandate is to share knowledge and transfer skills to make W&S utilities in low-income areas stronger, financially sustainable, and more climate resilient. This approach supports reducing gaps in service provision and promoting universalization of efficient, affordable, sustainable, and good quality services. It also supports government entities in developing policies that improve W&S services in rural and urban areas.

chunk_title: Description of Activities – Component I: Urban Utilities Performance Improvement
chunk: 3.1 Component I: This component will entail capacity building and knowledge transfer from VEI, accompanying the Colombian utilities in their work and systemically improving the maturity of their working processes through training, capacity development, and knowledge transfer.

chunk_title: Description of Activities – Component II: Water and Sanitation Rural & Urban Sectoral Dialogue
chunk: 3.2 Component II: This component will finance activities to support the National Government entities in charge of the W&S sector to strengthen their capacity and promote dialogue related to the improvement of W&S providers' performance.

chunk_title: Description of Activities – Component III: Non-Financial Solutions for Utilities’ Access to Financing
chunk: 3.3 Component III: Measures to bring closer supply and demand for financial resources will be implemented to reduce knowledge gaps between financiers and utilities.

chunk_title: Description of Activities – Component IV: Dissemination Activities
chunk: 3.4 Component IV: This component will finance activities to disseminate findings, experiences, and products coming from this TC and CO-T17772.

chunk_title: Description of Activities – Component V: External Audit
chunk: 3.5 Component V: An external audit will be funded to ensure accountability on the part of VEI as executing agency.

chunk_title: Executing Agency and Structure
chunk: 5.1 The Inter-American Development Bank through its Water and Sanitation Division will execute USD 1,026,000.00 and VEI will execute USD 400,000.00 from component 1.

chunk_title: Executing Agency – Complementarity with Previous TCs
chunk: 5.2 The Bank gained significant experience while executing prior Colombian TCs such as CO-T1417, CO-T1457, and CO-T1556, and will apply this to the current operation. The execution period will be 36 months with 3 additional months for disbursements.

chunk_title: Project Risks and Issues
chunk: 6.1 Working with government entities entails the risk of discontinuity due to slow response and staff changes at different levels. The TC will mitigate these risks through continuous dialogue and monitoring.

chunk_title: Environmental and Social Aspects
chunk: 7.1 This TC does not have applicable requirements of the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Main Objective
chunk: 2.1 The main objective of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to develop a sustainable technical and financial mechanism for the restoration, conservation, and monitoring of coral reefs in the Dominican Republic. This mechanism will integrate activities such as awareness campaigns, technical analysis, financing strategy design, pilot tests, and effectiveness evaluations to ensure its efficiency and scalability.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Coral Restoration Challenges and Link to Sanitation Program
chunk: 2.2 Coral restoration in the Dominican Republic faces significant challenges due to the lack of a sustainable financing system that ensures continuity and scaling of existing efforts. Current initiatives, though valuable, are temporary and fragmented, limiting their impact on biodiversity protection and the resilience of marine ecosystems. The absence of an integrated and long-term approach hinders the response to the accelerated loss of reefs. Therefore, this TC focuses on designing a technical and financial mechanism that structures and enhances available resources, ensuring restoration actions are sustainable, scalable, and effective in protecting natural capital and fostering coastal economic development. The activities financed by this TC complement and enhance the expected impact of the Program DR-L1165 (Universal Sanitation Program in Coastal and Tourist Cities of the Dominican Republic II), whose main objective is to improve access to quality sanitation services in coastal and tourist cities, prioritizing environmental sustainability and climate resilience. The program allocates US$1.5 million for coral reef recovery, recognizing their crucial role in coastal protection and biodiversity. Additional resources from this TC will be mobilized to design and implement a sustainable technical and financial mechanism, ensuring the continuity and scalability of coral restoration efforts. These resources accelerate the strategic actions of DR-L1165, integrating nature-based solutions with large infrastructure investments and reinforcing natural capital conservation and the resilience of coastal communities to the effects of climate change.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component I: Awareness and Participation
chunk: 3.1 Component I: Awareness, Mobilization and Participation for the Coral Restoration Mechanism. This component will build awareness, commitment, and active participation among the Dominican population and key public and private actors, integrating a gender and diversity approach along with behavioral change techniques.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component II: Technical Solutions and Scalability
chunk: 3.2 Component II: Analysis of Technical Solutions and Scalability Strategies for Coral Restoration. This component focuses on identifying, testing, and evaluating innovative technical solutions that incorporate local and regional perspectives in order to maximize their impact and applicability.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component III: Financial and Governance Mechanism
chunk: 3.3 Component III: Design of the Financial and Governance Mechanism for Coral Sustainability. This component will establish a financial and governance framework to ensure the sustainability of restoration efforts, integrating innovation, transparency, and inclusive participation, with a national-level monitoring approach to assess the status and evolution of coral reefs across the country.

chunk_title: Budget
chunk: IV. Budget. The indicative budget for this TC totals US$400,000.00, distributed across three components: (1) Awareness, Mobilization and Participation for the Coral Restoration Mechanism (US$70,000); (2) Analysis of Technical Solutions and Scalability Strategies for Coral Restoration (US$270,000); and (3) Design of the Financial and Governance Mechanism for Coral Sustainability (US$60,000).

chunk_title: Executing Agency, Risks and ESPF Alignment
chunk: V. Executing Agency and Execution Structure. At the request of the Government of the Dominican Republic, the Bank, through the Water and Sanitation Division (WSA), in collaboration with the Climate Change Division (CCS), will be responsible for implementing this TC by contracting consultancies to carry out the planned activities. The Bank will identify the necessary studies and technical work, select and hire consultants, and manage the execution and delivery of consultancy services following its established procurement procedures. The execution mechanism is justified because WSA, CCS and the IDB have substantial experience providing technical assistance in areas such as sanitation and water remediation, climate-friendly infrastructure, nature-based solutions, low-carbon technology, and implementation of nationally determined contributions. VI. Project Risks and Issues. Key risks include extreme natural phenomena such as hurricanes or severe storms that could damage or destroy restored corals or related infrastructure; lack of continuity in funding that could disrupt restoration and monitoring activities; challenges in inter-institutional coordination among public, private and NGO entities; and operational risks during pilot execution that could affect the effectiveness of the financing and restoration mechanism. Mitigation measures involve contingency actions, diversified and mandatory fundraising, clear governance and coordination frameworks, and detailed planning and monitoring of the pilot phase with flexibility for adjustments. VII. Environmental and Social Aspects. This TC does not have applicable requirements under the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Overall TC Objective
chunk: 2.1 Support the comprehensive preparation of water and drainage projects in Greater Santo Domingo, as well as water, sanitation, and reuse projects in coastal areas, particularly in Punta Cana and Bávaro, addressing technical, environmental, social, financial, and institutional aspects to ensure their sustainability and effective implementation.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Punta Cana–Bávaro Challenges
chunk: 2.2 The Punta Cana–Bávaro region faces significant challenges due to the absence of an integrated water and sanitation system. Water is extracted from unregulated wells and wastewater is poorly managed, threatening the aquifer, public health, and the tourism-based economy. The program will help address these gaps by supporting integrated infrastructure planning for potable water supply, wastewater treatment, and reuse.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Santo Domingo System Stress and Strategic Alignment
chunk: 2.3 In Santo Domingo, the capital and most densely populated urban center, the water supply system is under severe stress due to urban growth, high non-revenue water levels, and aging infrastructure. In 2022, over 1.6 million m³/day of potable water were produced, but only 39% of wastewater was collected. The proposed operation will strengthen water security by diversifying water sources, modernizing infrastructure, and improving water resource management. This Technical Cooperation is fully aligned with the IDB’s Institutional Strategy 2020–2030, particularly with its strategic priorities of (i) promoting social inclusion and equality by improving access to basic services such as water and sanitation; (ii) enhancing productivity and innovation by strengthening the efficiency and resilience of water infrastructure in key urban and tourism areas; and (iii) addressing climate change and environmental sustainability by promoting the protection of natural resources, climate-resilient investments, and the reuse of treated wastewater.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component I Studies
chunk: 3.1 Component I: 1. Technical, Environmental, and Social Studies. This component will finance the preparation of technical, environmental, and social studies required for the design of two operations: DR-L1172 (Punta Cana–Bávaro) and DR-L1171 (Santo Domingo).

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component II Institutional and Financial Assessments
chunk: 3.2 Component II: 2. Institutional, Financial, and Regulatory Assessments. This component will support the development of institutional diagnostics and financial and legal analyses to ensure the operational sustainability of both programs.

chunk_title: Budget
chunk: IV. Budget – Indicative Budget (in US$). Activity/Component: (1) Technical, Environmental, and Social Studies: IDB/Fund Funding US$400,000.00; Total Funding US$400,000.00. (2) Institutional, Financial, and Regulatory Assessments: IDB/Fund Funding US$150,000.00; Total Funding US$150,000.00. Total: IDB/Fund Funding US$550,000.00; Total Funding US$550,000.00.

chunk_title: Executing Agency and Execution Structure
chunk: V. Executing Agency and Execution Structure. 5.1 This Technical Cooperation (TC) will be executed by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), at the request of the Government of the Dominican Republic, in order to ensure the timely and high-quality preparation of two strategic and technically complex operations. Execution by the Bank is justified given the early design stage of both operations, which require a high degree of technical coordination, compliance with environmental and fiduciary standards, and the mobilization of specialized expertise. The IDB has substantial experience in providing technical assistance for the preparation of water and sanitation programs across the region, including the promotion of wastewater reuse in tourism-intensive and water-scarce areas, the design of public-private participation schemes, and the preparation of performance-based contracts such as those based on FIDIC standards. The Bank has also supported the incorporation of climate resilience and aquifer protection measures into water security programs in several countries. This accumulated experience will be applied to ensure the delivery of high-quality studies and technical inputs aligned with the objectives and scope of both operations. The TC will be executed by the Water and Sanitation Division (INE/WSA) in coordination with the IDB Country Office in the Dominican Republic. 5.2 The TC will be executed by the Bank through the hiring of consultancies to carry out the planned activities. In close dialogue with the public and private sectors, as well as other non-governmental institutions with technical capabilities and experience in the Dominican Republic, the Bank will be responsible for (i) identifying the necessary studies and technical work; (ii) selecting and hiring consultants to provide the necessary services; and (iii) managing the execution and delivery of the consulting services. All procurements to be executed under this TC will be contracted in accordance with the Bank's applicable policies and regulations.

chunk_title: Project Risks and Issues
chunk: VI. Project Risks and Issues. 6.1 The main risks include (i) lack of coordination among the institutions involved, particularly given the participation of both INAPA and the water utilities; and (ii) limited institutional ownership of the preparatory process. To mitigate these risks, the Bank team will organize periodic coordination meetings with the relevant government entities to ensure alignment and efficient information flow. In addition, the TC will finance components specifically aimed at strengthening institutional articulation and providing the technical support required to deliver high-quality products in a timely manner. The risk of limited institutional ownership will be mitigated by ensuring the direct participation of technical counterparts from the sector institutions in the preparation of the investment plans.

chunk_title: Environmental and Social Aspects
chunk: VII. Environmental and Social Aspects. 7.1 This Technical Cooperation is intended to finance pre-feasibility or feasibility studies of specific investment projects and the environmental and social studies associated with them; therefore, the terms of reference and products of this TC will be consistent with the applicable requirements of the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – General Objective
chunk: 2.1 The general objective of this TC is to promote the development, integration and scaling of innovative solutions in the water, sanitation and solid waste sector, which contribute to the achievement of universal access to quality water, sanitation and solid waste services, managed in an efficient manner, safely, sustainable and resilient. The specific objectives are (i) to promote the agenda of innovation and to foster alliances between actors; (ii) strengthen demand for innovative solutions; (iii) identify and support current and future loan operations.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Service Gaps and Climate Challenges
chunk: 2.2 In Mexico, water, sanitation and solid waste operators face challenges in several fronts, including improvement of efficiency and reduction of GHG emissions, management of water resources incorporating the impacts of climate change, resiliency against natural disasters, integrated solid waste management and circular economy. Although Mexico has high levels of potable water and sewerage coverage (96.1% in both cases, in 2020), in 2022, only 43% of the population had access to safe water supplies and 63% to hygienic sanitation services. These deficiencies have adverse impacts on the health and the economic welfare of the population.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Solid Waste, Innovation and Expected Benefits
chunk: Meanwhile, solid waste treatment—while high in terms of collection coverage—is affected by inadequate conditions for treatment and recycling, creating a risk of water pollution and increasing greenhouse gas emissions. In Mexico, 102,895.00 tons of urban waste are generated daily, of which 83.93% are collected and 78.54% are disposed of in final disposal sites, recycling only 9.63% of the waste generated. These services are legally under the jurisdiction of the municipal level; water and sanitation are usually managed by the same entity, while solid waste management has lacked attention and resources, contributing to the problem of inadequate solid waste disposal, including biosolids from wastewater treatment plants, worsening the pollution of surface and ground waters. With an increasing population and the growing effects of climate change, these challenges must be urgently addressed with insufficient time and resources; technological innovation can play a key role in providing more effective and faster solutions. Sector institutions in Mexico, such as the Ministry for the Environment and Natural Resources (SEMARNAT), National Water Commission (CONAGUA), National Association of Water and Sanitation Entities (ANEAS), also consider the role of innovation as crucial for the operators to be able to overcome these challenges. Newly appointed President, Claudia Sheinbaum, expressed her commitment to promoting innovation; among her key projects, the development of technological solutions for the efficient use of water and energy was included as part of a new technological development plan for Mexico. This technical cooperation can, thus, help setting up financing schemes and operations, by supporting the elaboration of such studies and pre-investment projects, duly considering Japanese innovation and state-of-the art expertise. The TC will directly benefit sectoral organizations related to water, sanitation, and solid waste, and indirectly benefit households and users of these services in Mexico. It is expected that the adoption and/or adaptation of innovative solutions (e.g., innovative management models, or technologies for loss reduction, etc.) will contribute to supporting the efforts of the countries in the region to achieve sectoral sustainable development goals, duly considering the potential impacts of climate change emergencies and natural disasters.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component I
chunk: 3.1 Component I: Strengthening national innovation ecosystem and identification of new projects. Analyze key aspects of the ecosystem and the demand for solutions, identifying opportunities for innovation in the sector. Consulting services will be funded for (i) intelligence and diagnostics focused on strengthening innovation units; (ii) development and application of methodologies and tools; (iii) identification and introduction of solutions; and (iv) development of a study and technical note on Japan's cutting-edge solutions focused on solid waste management.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component II
chunk: 3.2 Component II: Promotion of the innovation agenda and fostering of alliances between actors. (i) open innovation events and calls; (ii) strengthening, exchange, and dialogue among service providers, innovators, and investors in Mexico, as well as between Mexico and other countries; (iii) dissemination and enhancement of knowledge products on innovation. Under this component, the Bank will incorporate lessons learned from relevant activities and disseminate existing knowledge products, including the participation of Japanese experts and innovative solutions.

chunk_title: Executing Agency, Execution Structure, Risks and ESPF Alignment
chunk:
V. Executing Agency and Execution Structure
5.1 Due to federal budgetary reasons in the country the TC will be executed by the Bank, through the Water and Sanitation Division (WSA). The Terms of Reference for the activities will be finalized in coordination with the sector institutions (water, sanitation and solid waste operators, SEMARNAT, CONAGUA, and/or ANEAS). 5.2 All procurement to be executed under this TC will be hired in compliance with the applicable Bank policies and regulations as follows: (a) Hiring of individual consultants, as established in the regulation on Complementary Workforce (AM-650) and (b) Contracting of services provided by consulting firms and non-consulting services in accordance with the Corporate procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its Guidelines. Monitoring and Evaluation. The execution monitoring will be carried out through the following mechanisms: (i) technical working meetings between the water and sanitation IDB's team in Mexico and the consultants; (ii) IDB’s review (and eventually the beneficiaries’ entities) of the technical reports to be presented by the consultants; and (iii) coordination meetings. From the date of the signing of the first consultancy contract, at the end of each year, and after the closing date, the IDB team will address all relevant CT reporting and evaluation requirements, including at least: (i) description of progress; (ii) relevant technical aspects to highlight; and (iii) execution problems and pending issues.
VI. Project Risks and Issues
6.1 The major risk during the execution of this TC is the potential delay in execution of the consulting services due to a lack of coordination between the Bank, as the Executing Agency, and Mexican sector institutions. To mitigate this risk, the Bank’s team will maintain regular meetings with such institutions. WSA has significant experience executing TCs in the water, sanitation and solid waste sector that requires close coordination with the counterparts, and the division has very solid capacity locally in the Country Office of Mexico.
VII. Environmental and Social Aspects
7.1 This Technical Cooperation is intended to finance pre-feasibility or feasibility studies of specific investment projects and the environmental and social studies associated with them; therefore, the terms of reference and products of this TC will be consistent with the applicable requirements of the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Knowledge Dissemination on Water Security
chunk: 2.1 The objective of this technical cooperation is to share knowledge products developed through the implementation of the Water Security Strategy and the Transboundary Program of INE/WSA at the COP 30 and events pre-COP. This includes promoting the recently approved program funded by GCF and IDB, “Improving Climate Resilience by Increasing Water Security in the Amazon Basin.” While this TC focuses on the Amazon basin, it will also incorporate technical expertise and lessons learned from TCs executed in other regions of LAC. The aim is to provide reference knowledge products from these regions on water resilience, that can serve as replicable case studies for the Amazon, particularly in the context of COP30 in Belém, Brazil. The specific objectives of this TC are: (1) support the development and dissemination of knowledge products and communication materials on water resilience and the implementation of Nature-based Solutions (NbS) in the water and sanitation sector, (2) facilitate technical and political dialogues related to these knowledge products in preparation for the COP30, and (3) promote the dissemination of the GCF Water Security Program in the Amazon.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Importance of the Amazon Basin
chunk: 2.2 The Amazon basin hosts the world’s largest tropical rainforest, making it a global center of biological diversity. As the largest hydrographic basin in the world, it produces nearly 20% of the planet's freshwater and contains 25% of the world's terrestrial biodiversity. In South America, it represents 70% of the freshwater discharge, playing a vital role in regulating climate patterns, sustaining ecosystems, ensuring water, food and energy security, and supporting the livelihoods of local communities. Furthermore, the Amazon is crucial to climate resilience as it naturally sequesters approximately 150–200 billion tons of carbon dioxide in soils and vegetation, functioning as one of the planet’s largest carbon sinks.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component I
chunk: 3.1 Component I: Knowledge Generation. It will develop a minimum of three (3) technical notes focused on Nature Based Solutions (NbS) and their application in water adaptation projects. The aim of these technical notes is to present at COP30 in Belém knowledge products that, regardless of whether they specifically focus on the Amazon, showcase advances in the application of NbS in the water sector, with the potential for scaling up.

chunk_title: Description of Activities and Outputs – Component II
chunk: 3.2 Component II: Knowledge Sharing and Outreach. It will focus on the dissemination of knowledge products on water resilience in strategic pre-COP30 webinars and events, where technical studies will be shared to inform policy discussions. The TC will also showcase the capacity building provided throughout the past years to the Amazon Cooperation Treaty Organization (ACTO), a key partner in the development of technical notes, strengthening the knowledge development and technical capacity of the Amazon Regional Observatory (ARO).

chunk_title: Description of Activities – Component III
chunk: 3.3 Component III: Dissemination of the GCF Water Security Program in the Amazon. It is designed to strategically disseminate information about the GCF Water Security Program within high-level technical and political forums, as well as among stakeholders. This goal includes the dissemination of the Program’s Gender and Diversity Strategy, which outlines specific actions to improve access to resources and opportunities for Indigenous Peoples and Afro-descendant communities in the Amazon region.

chunk_title: Budget
chunk: IV. Budget – Indicative Budget (in US$): Component I Knowledge Generation: $50,000. Component II Knowledge Sharing and Outreach: $50,000. Component III Dissemination of the GCF Water Security Program in the Amazon: $50,000. Total: $150,000.

chunk_title: Executing Agency & Structure
chunk: 5.1 The Bank, through its Water and Sanitation Division (INE/WSA), in coordination with CSC/ACU, will serve as the executing entity for this TC. The Bank’s role as the Executing Agency is justified by its leadership in implementing the TCs from which the technical notes and knowledge products to be disseminated under this TC were developed. Insights will also support the development of new knowledge products on NbS in the water sector, climate adaptation and the WEF nexus approach.

chunk_title: Execution, Procurement, and Risk Management
chunk: 5.2 INE/WSA will also be the Unit of Disbursement Responsibility (UDR) and will oversee procurement processes. The work plan includes the Procurement Plan and compliance with IDB policies for hiring individual consultants and consulting firms. The project schedule spans 24 months. Coordination with key partners such as ACTO will ensure timely delivery. Minor risks include tight timelines for COP30 and insufficient detail for effective policy dialogue.
